[[File:Navy-FloodedNewOrleans.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Flooding in [[Downtown New Orleans|Downtown]] [[New Orleans]] caused by Hurricane Katrina|alt=Aerial view of a downtown area of a city in the background and suburbs in the foreground inundated by floodwater. Except for the highways, nearly every street is completely covered in water. Various buildings, particularly the dome shaped building in the center, show damage.]]
From 2000 to the present, at least 28 [[tropical cyclones|tropical]] or [[subtropical cyclone]]s affected the [[U.S. state]] of [[Louisiana]]. According to David Roth of the [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]] (HPC), a tropical cyclone makes [[Landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] along the coastline about two times every three years, and a hurricane makes landfall once every 2.8 years.<ref name="LA Hurricanes">{{cite book|title=Louisiana Hurricane History|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/lahur.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=[[National Weather Service|United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service]]|accessdate=December 28, 2012|author=Roth, David M|author2=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center}}</ref>
The most active month for tropical cyclone activity in the state is September, with ten total storms, while no recorded storms have affected Louisiana during the months of December through May. The most intense storm to affect the state in terms of [[barometric pressure]] is [[Hurricane Katrina]] of 2005, which also caused the most fatalities and damage with 1,833 total deaths and over $100 billion in total damages.{{#tag:ref|All damage totals are in the value of the [[United States dollar|USD]] during the storm's year of existence.|group="nb"}} Katrina is also the [[List of costliest Atlantic hurricanes|second costliest]] hurricane in the Atlantic basin. In terms of [[wind speed]], Hurricane Katrina is also the 2nd strongest storm to affect the state,(Right behind Hurricane Rita which also hit in 2005), producing [[maximum sustained winds]] of {{convert|125|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, equivalent to [[Category 3 hurricane|Category 3]] on the [[Saffir–Simpson hurricane scale]].
==2000–2004== [[File:TS Allison-LA.jpg|thumb|right|Flooding from Tropical Storm Allison in [[Chackbay, Louisiana|Chackbay]]]] *September 9, 2000 – [[2000 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Nine|Tropical Depression Nine]] makes landfall near the [[Texas]] and Louisiana border as a tropical depression with winds of {{convert|30|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name=td9>{{cite web|title=Tropical Depression Nine|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000nine.html |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=14 December 2012 |author=Beven, Jack L. |date=November 17, 2000 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202151035/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2000nine.html |archivedate= 2 December 2012 |df=}}</ref> Although the depression makes landfall on Texas, most of the rain associated with the system affects Louisiana, where rainfall peaks at {{convert|6.70|in|cm|abbr=on}}.<ref name=td9rain>{{cite web|title=Tropical Depression #9 - September 5-10, 2000|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/td92000.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=14 December 2012|author=Roth, David M.}}</ref> At the coast, Tropical Depression Nine brings a [[storm surge]] peaking at {{convert|3|ft|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name=td9ingulf>{{cite news|title=Tropical depression forms in gulf|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/090900/Worldandnation/National_briefs.shtml|accessdate=14 December 2012|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=September 9, 2000}}</ref> In [[Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana|Terrebonne Parish]], strong [[thunderstorm]] winds associated with the depression damage trailers and boats in Bayou Black, resulting in $2,500 in damages.<ref name=stormdatasept2000>{{cite journal|title=September 2000|journal=Storm Data|date=September 2000|volume=42|issue=9|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-A15476CC-6DC1-4CD3-B965-F1A1967C95C5.pdf|accessdate=14 December 2012|author=United States Department of Commerce|editor1-first=Stephen|editor1-last=Del Greco|page=59|location=Asheville, North Carolina}}</ref> *Early–June 2001 – [[Tropical Storm Allison]] makes landfall near [[Freeport, Texas]] on June 5, consequently stalling over the state before moving offshore and subsequently making a second landfall on [[Morgan City, Louisiana|Morgan City]] as a subtropical depression on June 11 with winds of {{convert|30|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and a minimum pressure of {{convert|1004|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}}.<ref name="AllisonTCR">{{cite report|author=Stewart, Stacy R.|title=Tropical Storm Allison Tropical Cyclone Report |date=February 28, 2001 |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=28 December 2012 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001allison.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916074527/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001allison.html |archivedate=16 September 2008 |df=}}</ref> This results in catastrophic flooding across the state.<ref name=allisonrain>{{cite web|title=Tropical Storm Allison - June 4-18, 2001|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/allison2001.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|author=Roth, David M.}}</ref> Rainfall from Allison peaks at {{convert|29.92|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Thibodaux, Louisiana|Thibodaux]],<ref name="Rainfall Totals for Gulf Coast">{{cite web|title=Tropical Cyclone Rainfall for the Gulf Coast|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/tcgulfcoast.html|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service|author=Roth, David M.|author2=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=December 28, 2012}}</ref> ranking as the second–wettest tropical cyclone in state history, only behind a [[1940 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|hurricane in 1940]].<ref name=allison52>{{cite web|title=HPC Storm Summary #52 for T.D. Allison|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical2001/allison/06190109.html|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Weather Service|accessdate=28 December 2012|author=Roth, David M.|author2=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center's Forecast Operations Branch|author3=National Centers for Environmental Prediction|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222020801/http://www.hpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical2001/allison/06190109.html|archivedate=December 22, 2007|location=Camp Springs, Maryland|date=June 20, 2011}}</ref> Major river flooding occurs in [[Amite River]] and [[Comite River]], which experience their highest water levels since 1983. Homes are destroyed and swept away by flooding across the state.<ref name=stormdatajune2001>{{cite journal|title=June 2001|journal=Storm Data|date=June 2001|volume=43|issue=6|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-85088283-50AD-4F71-A9C0-C499A1873A19.pdf|accessdate=28 December 2012|author=United States Department of Commerce|author2=National Environmental Satellite, Data and Information Service|author3=National Climatic Data Center|editor1-first=Stephen|editor1-last=Del Greco|editor2-first=Stuart|editor2-last=Hinson|editor3-first=Rhonda|editor3-last=Mooring|page=152|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|location=Asheville, North Carolina}}</ref> In [[Zachary, Louisiana|Zachary]], a man is killed after a [[tornado]] knocks a tree onto his truck.<ref name="LA Hurricanes" /> Damages from Tropical Storm Allison in Louisiana alone total to $65 million.<ref name=allisoneventreport>{{cite report|author=Risk Management Solutions|title=Tropical Storm Allison, June 2001|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url=http://www.rms.com/Publications/TS_Allison.pdf|page=1}}</ref> *August 6, 2001 – [[Tropical Storm Barry (2001)|Tropical Storm Barry]] causes tides of {{convert|2|–|3|ft|m|abbr=on}} along the southeastern coast of Louisiana before it makes landfall on [[Santa Rosa Beach, Florida]] on August 6. Prior to making landfall, tropical storm [[tropical storm watch|watches]] and [[tropical storm warning|warnings]] are issued along the Gulf Coast, west to [[New Orleans]].<ref name=BarryTCR>{{cite report|author=Beven, Jack|title=Tropical Storm Barry Tropical Cyclone Report|date=April 22, 2002|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001barry.html}}</ref> *August 5, 2002 – [[Tropical Storm Bertha (2002)|Tropical Storm Bertha]] makes landfall on [[Boothville, Louisiana|Boothville]] as a minimal tropical storm with wind speeds of {{convert|40|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and a minimum pressure of {{convert|1008|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}}, moving across Louisiana as a weakening system before moving back into the Gulf of Mexico on August 7.<ref name=BerthaTCR>{{cite report|author=Beven, Jack|title=Tropical Storm Bertha Tropical Cyclone Report|date=November 20, 2002|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002bertha.shtml}}</ref> The storm drops scattered rainfall across the state, peaking southwest of [[Franklinton, Louisiana|Franklinton]] at {{convert|10.25|in|cm|abbr=on}}.<ref name=bertharain>{{cite web|title=Tropical Storm Bertha - August 3-9, 2002|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/bertha2002.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|author=Roth, David M.}}</ref> Streets were flooded by the heavy rainfall in [[Slidell, Louisiana|Slidell]].<ref name=berthadumpsrain>{{cite news|title=Storm Bertha dumps rain along Gulf Coast|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QMkNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HXQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5847,42386&dq=tropical+storm+bertha&hl=en|accessdate=28 December 2012|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=August 6, 2002|agency=Associated Press|location=New Orleans, Louisiana|page=3A}}</ref> In [[St. Tammany Parish]], [[surface runoff]] from [[flash flooding]] causes some rivers to exceed flood stage.<ref name=stormdataaug2002>{{cite journal|title=August 2002|journal=Storm Data|date=August 2002|volume=44|issue=8|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-3EEA9D8A-CA6D-4E45-93A5-052B3C7B8893.pdf|accessdate=28 December 2012|author=United States Department of Commerce|editor1-first=William|editor1-last=Angel|page=98|location=Asheville, North Carolina}}</ref> *September 5, 2002 – [[Tropical Storm Fay (2002)|Tropical Storm Fay]] develops offshore the Louisiana coast before making landfall in Texas as a moderate tropical storm. West of [[Cameron, Louisiana|Cameron]], Fay causes a [[storm surge]] as high as {{convert|2.5|ft|m|abbr=on}}, resulting in minor [[beach erosion]] and coastal highway flooding.<ref name=FayTCR>{{cite report|author=Stewart, Stacy R.|title=Tropical Storm Fay Tropical Cyclone Report|date=June 23, 2003|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002fay.shtml}}</ref> Tropical Storm Fay's outer rainbands drop light rainfall over eastern and southern portions of the state, peaking at {{convert|4.64|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Grand Isle, Louisiana|Grand Isle]].<ref name="Rainfall Totals for Gulf Coast" /> Prior to making landfall, a tropical storm warning is issued for western parts of Louisiana east to [[Intracoastal City, Louisiana|Intracoastal City]].<ref name=faythreatens>{{cite news|title=Tropical Storm Fay threatens Texas, Louisiana|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2002-09-06/weather/tropical.storm.fay_1_port-o-connor-intracoastal-city-rain-on-coastal-areas?_s=PM:WEATHER|accessdate=28 December 2012|date=September 6, 2002|agency=Cable News Network}}</ref> *September 14, 2002 – [[Tropical Storm Hanna (2002)|Tropical Storm Hanna]] makes landfall near the [[mouth (river)|mouth]] of the [[Mississippi River]] as a moderate tropical storm with winds of {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, before subsequently making landfall on the border between [[Alabama]] and [[Mississippi]].<ref name=HannaTCR>{{cite report|author=Franklin, James L.|author2=Rhome, Jamie R.|title=Tropical Storm Hanna Tropical Cyclone Report|date=December 16, 2002|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002hanna.shtml}}</ref> Despite making landfall on Louisiana, as a result of [[convection]] displaced east of the center, the state receives primarily minimal effects from Hanna. No significant flooding resulted from high [[tide]]s caused by the storm.<ref name=stormdatasept2002>{{cite journal|title=September 2002|journal=Storm Data|date=September 2002|volume=44|issue=9|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-85088283-50AD-4F71-A9C0-C499A1873A19.pdf|accessdate=28 December 2012|author=United States Department of Commerce|author2=National Environmental Satellite, Data and Information Service|author3=National Climatic Data Center|editor1-first=William|editor1-last=Angel|editor2-first=Stuart|editor2-last=Hinson|editor3-first=Rhonda|editor3-last=Mooring|page=65|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|location=Asheville, North Carolina}}</ref> Rainfall is confined to extreme eastern portions of the state, where rainfall peaks at {{convert|1.72|in|cm|abbr=on}} in Sondeheimer, Louisiana.<ref name="Rainfall Totals for Gulf Coast" />
[[File:Tropical Storm Isidore (2002).gif|thumb|Tropical Storm Isidore making its Louisiana landfall|alt=Colorized image of a hurricane with no eye, but clear banding features. Darker magenta shades indicate strong thunderstorms, and lighter, bluer shades indicate weaker convection.]] *September 26, 2002 – [[Hurricane Isidore]] makes landfall just west of [[Grand Isle, Louisiana|Grand Isle]] as a Tropical Storm with winds of {{convert|65|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, having significantly weakened after stalling over the [[Yucatán Peninsula]].<ref name=IsidoreTCR>{{cite report|author=Avila, Lixion A.|title=Hurricane Isidore Tropical Cyclone Report|date=December 20, 2002|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=17 March 2013|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002isidore.shtml}}</ref> Rainfall is widespread across the state, peaking at {{convert|15.97|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Metarie, Louisiana|Metarie]].<ref name="Rainfall Totals for Gulf Coast" /> The heavy rains cause the failure of drainage systems, leaving numerous streets flooded. In Terrebonne Parish, 200–300 homes are flooded. The rains also damage large plots of sugar cane crop in Southwest Louisiana.<ref name=stormdatasept2002 /> *October 3, 2002 – [[Hurricane Lili]] made landfall on the morning of October 3 near Intracoastal City, as a weakening category 1 hurricane. Wind gusts reaching {{convert|120|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, coupled with over {{convert|6|in|mm}} of rainfall and a storm surge of {{convert|12|ft|m}} caused over $790 million (2002 USD) in damage to Louisiana. A total of 237,000 people lost power, and oil rigs offshore were shut down for up to a week. Crops were badly affected, particularly the sugar cane, damage totaled nearly $175 million (2002 USD). No direct deaths were reported as early warnings and the compact nature of the storm circumvented major loss of life. *June 30, 2003 – [[Tropical Storm Bill (2003)|Tropical Storm Bill]] brought a moderate storm surge peaking at {{convert|5.8|ft|m|abbr=on}} at the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium facility in [[Chauvin, Louisiana|Chauvin]]. In [[Montegut, Louisiana|Montegut]], the surge breached a levee still was damaged from the effects of Hurricane Lili 9 months before. The breach flooded many homes in the town, forcing the evacuation of an entire neighborhood. As a result, 150 homes in the town were damaged, with half of them severely. The storm surge affected numerous low-lying cities in southeastern Louisiana by flooding roadways, including the only road to Grand Isle, stranding residents and visitors. The floodwaters entered a few homes and businesses in St. Tammany Parish. Damage from the storm surge totaled to $4.1 million (2003 USD). Rough waves sank two boats offshore, though their occupants were rescued. *August 31, 2003 – [[Tropical Storm Grace (2003)|Tropical Storm Grace]] drops light rainfall across the state. *September 15–16 and September 22-23, 2004 – Around the time [[Hurricane Ivan]]'s initial landfall in Alabama, the storm produced wind gusts as strong as {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at the [[Southwest Pass (Mississippi River)|Southwest Pass]] of the Mississippi River. In Plaquemines Parish, several school and government building as well as about 100 mobile homes. Additionally, about 50 electrical poles were toppled. About a dozen structure in St. Bernard Parish were damaged. Storm surge flooded several low-lying areas in southeastern Louisiana. About 55,000 customers lost power during the storm. Four people died during evacuation and damage in the state reached roughly $7.9 million. Upon the storm's second landfall in [[Holly Beach, Louisiana|Holly Beach]] resulted in minor coastal flooding, with damage totaling only about $15,000. Inland, generally light rainfall was recorded. *October 10, 2004 – [[Tropical Storm Matthew (2004)|Tropical Storm Matthew]] caused a storm surge of up to {{convert|5.85|ft|m|abbr=on}} in Frenier. The storm surge and waves resulted in significant beach erosion in Grand Isle. Portions of Louisiana experienced significant rainfall, including a peak of {{convert|18|in|mm}} in [[Haynesville, Louisiana|Haynesville]]. In addition, a tornado caused damage to the roof of a trailer in Golden Meadow. Rainfall and storm surge flooded 20 homes in Terrebonne Parish. In addition, several homes in Lafouche Parish experienced flooding, including two with over two feet of water. Numerous homes in Golden Meadow experienced flooding, as well. The flooding also forced the temporary closing of numerous roads across the state, including portions of [[U.S. Route 11|Route 11]] and [[Interstate 10]]. Flood waters from the storm cracked a water line in [[LaPlace, Louisiana|LaPlace]], leaving nearly 30,000 residents and many businesses without tap water. The problem was expected to take little time to fix, though residents were advised to boil the water before drinking it. Matthew also left 2,500 people without power for a short period of time. The storm's impact also closed several schools. In all, Matthew caused $255,000 in damage (2004 USD).
==2005–2009== [[File:Katrina 2nd landfall.jpg|thumb|Hurricane Katrina making landfall on Louisiana|alt=Satellite image of a hurricane making landfall. The hurricane has an eye.]]
*July 5, 2005 – [[Hurricane Cindy (2005)|Hurricane Cindy]] brought wind gusts of {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} to New Orleans, downing many trees. Rainfall also left scattered street flooding. With thousands losing electrical power, the city experienced its worst blackout since [[Hurricane Betsy]] in 1965, only to be trumped by Hurricane Katrina less than eight weeks later. *July 10, 2005 – [[Hurricane Dennis]] produced light precipitation and a wind gust of {{convert|47|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Lakefront Airport]] in New Orleans. *August 29, 2005 – Storm surge from [[Hurricane Katrina]] resulted in multiple levee failures in the New Orleans area, flooding approximately 80% of the city, with some places being inundated by more than {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} of water. The failures of the levees were considered the worst engineering disaster in the history of the United States. Thousands of people were stranded inside their homes or on rooftops and required rescue from boats and helicopters. Many buildings and homes were damaged, with 134,000 housing units – approximately 70% of residences in New Orleans – were impacted to some degree. The [[Mercedes-Benz Superdome|Superdome]], which was sheltering many people who had not evacuated, sustained significant damage. Two sections of the Superdome's roof were compromised and the dome's waterproof membrane had essentially been peeled off. The famous [[French Quarter]] and [[Garden District, New Orleans|Garden District]] escaped flooding because those area are above sea level. A total of 573 deaths occurred in New Orleans alone.<br> Several other parishes were severely impacted by the storm. Many areas outside of New Orleans also suffered wind damage, especially St. Tammany and Washington parishes. According to the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, in St. Bernard Parish, 81% (20,229) of the housing units were damaged. In St. Tammany Parish, 70% (48,792) were damaged, and in Placquemines Parish 80% (7,212) were damaged. Nearly 900,000 Louisianians were left without electricity. Throughout the state, 1,577 fatalities were reported. Overall, it is estimated that Hurricane Katrina caused $108 billion in damage throughout the Southern United States, with much of the damage occurring in Louisiana and Mississippi. *September 24, 2005 – [[Hurricane Rita]] makes Landfall as a Category 3 Hurricane On the Texas-Louisiana border. Winds were 120mph (193 km/h) *September 13, 2007 – [[Hurricane Humberto (2007)|Hurricane Humberto]] *September 22, 2007 – [[Tropical Depression Ten (2007)|Tropical Depression Ten]] *August 4, 2008 – [[Tropical Storm Edouard (2008)|Tropical Storm Edouard]] *August 31, 2008 – [[Hurricane Gustav]] reached the Louisiana coast on the morning of September 1, making landfall near Cocodrie, Louisiana. The center of the storm continued northwest across the state, so damage and deaths were widespread in many areas; 34 parishes were declared as disaster areas. *September 13, 2008 - [[Hurricane Ike (2008)|Hurricane Ike]] *November 10, 2009 – [[Hurricane Ida (2009)|Hurricane Ida]]
==2010–2017== [[File:Hurricane Isaac - CPRA - Grand Isle.jpg|thumb|right|[[Grand Isle, Louisiana|Grand Isle]] inundated after the passage of Hurricane Isaac in August 2012]] *July 25–26, 2010 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2010)|Tropical Storm Bonnie]] produced a localized heavy rain event on July 25, with {{convert|8|to|9|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain falling in [[West Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana|West Baton Rouge Parish]]. More than 100 homes were flooded and 20 bridges and roads were washed away. Severe weather related to the system caused further damage the following day. In all, damage from Bonnie amounted to $810,000.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010 |accessdate=October 21, 2010 |title=Louisiana Event Report: Flash Flood |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~823499 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5teNqNPPc?url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~823499 |archivedate=October 21, 2010 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center |year=2010 |accessdate=October 21, 2010 |title=Louisiana Event Report: Flash Flood |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~823501 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5tebVoddh?url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~823501 |archivedate=October 21, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center |year=2010 |accessdate=October 21, 2010 |title=Louisiana Event Report: Thunderstorm Winds |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~824197 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5teOGoEZO?url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~824197 |archivedate=October 21, 2010 |df= }}</ref> *Mid–August 2010 – [[Tropical Depression Five (2010)|Tropical Depression Five]] - The remnants of Tropical Depression Five make two separate landfalls within the state. Upon its classification as a Tropical Depression, the [[National Hurricane Center]] issues a [[Tropical cyclone warnings and watches|tropical storm warning]] for much of southern Louisiana, including [[New Orleans]]. The storm ultimately dissipates prior to reaching the coastline, and the remnants of the cyclone produce riptides and strong waves along the coast. A local National Weather Service office issues [[Flood alert|flood watches]] for up to twelve Louisiana parishes. As the remnants of the cyclone regain strength in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] and approach the state for a second time, a [[coastal flood watch]] is issued for southern portions of the state. Up to sixteen hours of intense rain and thunderstorms flood at least 40 buildings and structures in [[Avoyelles Parish, Louisiana]]. *September 4, 2011 – [[Tropical Storm Lee (2011)|Tropical Storm Lee]] - A state of emergency is declared for [[New Orleans]] ahead of Lee, with the threat of the storm prompting the preparation of rescue boats across the city and city officials ordering the closure of [[floodgate]]s. Due to its slow and erratic motion across the state, Lee drops torrential rainfall across much of southern Louisiana. [[Headwind and tailwind|Headwinds]] from the storm fan a large and destructive fire in [[Natchitoches Parish, Louisiana]], where about 400 acres of land is set ablaze and subsequently destroyed. In addition, several homes in [[Slidell, Louisiana|Slidell]] are inundated by a four-foot storm surge. New Orleans also suffers sporadic power outages, but escapes with only minor flooding. *June 23–24, 2012 – Initially forecast to brush the state as a hurricane,<ref name="DebbyTCR"/> [[Tropical Storm Debby (2012)|Tropical Storm Debby]] prompted a state of emergency.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/06/24/12383269-tropical-storm-debby-turns-sights-on-florida-alabama-gulf-oil-production-curtailed?lite|title=Tropical Storm Debby turns sights on Florida, Alabama; Gulf oil production curtailed|date=June 24, 2012|newspaper=[[NBC News]]|accessdate=March 30, 2013}}</ref> The storm ultimately tracked far right of early predictions and struck Florida. Several days of onshore flow led to a storm surge in southeastern areas of the state, peaking at {{convert|2.68|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Shell Beach, Louisiana|Shell Beach]].<ref name="DebbyTCR">{{cite report|author=Todd B. Kimberlain|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|date=February 21, 2013|accessdate=November 13, 2015|title=Tropical Storm Debby|series=Tropical Cyclone Report|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL042012_Debby}}|format=PDF|location=Miami, Florida}}</ref> *August 29, 2012 – [[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]] - Isaac comes ashore the state twice as a large Category 1 hurricane, producing an eleven-foot storm surge in Shell Beach. The storm produces sustained tropical storm-force winds and hurricane-force wind gusts in [[Grand Isle, Louisiana|Grand Isle]], leaving over 600,000 customers without power across the state. However, the most severe effects of the hurricane are reported in [[New Orleans metropolitan area|Metropolitan New Orleans]], where the majority of residents are left without power. In addition, many pumping stations in [[Slidell, Louisiana|Slidell]] were unable to keep up with rainfall rates and the city suffered flood damage as a result. *October 6, 2013 – A state of emergency was declared ahead of [[2013 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Karen|Tropical Storm Karen]];<ref>{{cite news|title=Latest track shows weaker Karen making hard right turn|url=http://www.wesh.com/weather/tropical-storm-karen/22228496|newspaper=WESH TV|accessdate=April 17, 2014|date=October 6, 2013|location=Orlando, Florida}}</ref> however, the storm dissipated over the northern Gulf of Mexico and had negligible effects in the state.<ref>{{cite report|author=Todd B. Kimberlain|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|date=January 8, 2014|accessdate=November 13, 2015|title=Tropical Storm Karen|series=Tropical Cyclone Report|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL122013_Karen}}|format=PDF|location=Miami, Florida}}</ref> Rainfall was predominantly less than {{convert|1|in|mm|abbr=on}}, with a localized peak around {{convert|3|in|mm|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|publisher=[[Weather Prediction Center]]|date=n.d.|accessdate=November 13, 2015|title=Tropical Storm Karen - October 3–15, 2013|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/karen2013.html|location=College Park, Maryland}}</ref> *June 16–18, 2015 – [[Tropical Storm Bill (2015)|Tropical Storm Bill]] *June 22, 2017 – [[Tropical Storm Cindy (2017)|Tropical Storm Cindy]] *Late–August 2017 – [[Hurricane Harvey]] *October 8, 2017 – [[Hurricane Nate (2017)|Hurricane Nate]]
==Monthly statistics== {{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting Louisiana | data_max = 15 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label1 = January | data1 = | label2 = February | data2 = | label3 = March | data3 = | label4 = April | data4 = | label5 = May | data5 = | label6 = June | data6 = 4 | label7 = July | data7 = 3 | label8 = August | data8 = 10 | label9 = September | data9 = 10 | label10 = October | data10 = 3 | label11 = November | data11 = 1 | label12 = December | data12 = }}
==Deadly storms== The following is a list of hurricanes that caused known deaths in the state.
<center> {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ Hurricanes causing known deaths in Louisiana |- ! scope="col" | Name ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Number of deaths ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes |- ! scope="row" | [[Hurricane Katrina|Katrina]] | [[2005 Atlantic hurricane season|2005]] | 1,833 | <ref name="LA Hurricanes" /> |- ! scope="row" | [[Hurricane Gustav|Gustav]] | [[2008 Atlantic hurricane season|2008]] | 7 | <ref name="GustavTCR">{{cite report|author=Beven II, John L.|author2=Kimberlain, Todd B.|title=Hurricane Gustav|work=Tropical Cyclone Report|date=September 15, 2009|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL072008_Gustav}}}}</ref> |- ! scope="row" | [[Tropical Storm Allison|Allison]] | [[2001 Atlantic hurricane season|2001]] | 1 | <ref name=allisoneventreport /> |- ! scope="row" | [[Hurricane Isidore|Isidore]] | [[2002 Atlantic hurricane season|2002]] | 1 | <ref name="IsidoreTCR">{{cite report|author=Avila, Lixion A.|title=Hurricane Isidore|work=Tropical Cyclone Report|date=December 20, 2002|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2002isidore.shtml}}</ref> |- ! scope="row" | [[Hurricane Rita|Rita]] | 2005 | 1 | <ref name="RitaTCR">{{cite report|author=Knabb, Richard D.|author2=Brown, Daniel P.|author3=Rhome, Jamier R.|title=Hurricane Rita|work=Tropical Cyclone Report|date=September 14, 2011|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=28 December 2012|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL182005_Rita}}}}</ref> |- |} </center>
==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} *[[List of Atlantic hurricane seasons]] *[[List of Atlantic hurricanes]] *[[List of wettest tropical cyclones in the United States#Louisiana|List of wettest known tropical cyclones affecting Louisiana]]

This is a '''list of colleges of natural resources''' around the world, offering [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]], [[Master's degree|master's]] or [[Doctor of philosophy|doctoral]] degrees in natural resource science, [[natural resource management]], or related fields. {{expand list|date=August 2014}} {{TOC right}}
== Austria == *[[University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences, Vienna]]
== Bhutan == *[[College of Natural Resources (Bhutan)|College of Natural Resources]], Lobesa, [[Punakha District]]
== Canada == * Faculty of Natural Resources Management, [[Lakehead University]] * Faculty of Natural Resources Management, [[University of Northern British Columbia]]
== Ethiopia == * [http://www.hu.edu.et/cfnr/ Wondo Genet College of Forestry and Natural Resources], [[Hawassa University]]
== Ghana == * [[College of Agriculture and Natural Resources]], [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]] * Department of Renewable Natural Resources, [[University for Development Studies]]
== India == * [[College of Fisheries]], Mangalore, Karnataka
== Iran== * [[Gorgan University|Gorgan University of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources]]
== Norway == * Department of Ecology and Natural Resources, [[Norwegian University of Life Sciences]]
== Philippines == * College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources, [[Caraga State University]]<ref>[http://carsu.edu.ph Caraga State University website]</ref> * [[University of the Philippines Los Baños College of Forestry and Natural Resources]] * College of Forestry and Natural Resources, [[Visayas State University]]
==Sudan== * College of Natural Resources and Environmental Studies, [[University of Juba]] * Faculty of Natural Resources and Environmental Studies, [[University of Kordofan]]
== Taiwan == * Department of Forestry and Natural Resources, [[National Chiayi University]] * Department of Forestry and Natural Resources, [[National Ilan University]]
==United Kingdom== * School of the Environment, Natural Resources and Geography, [[Bangor University]]
== United States ==

===Midwest=== * Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Sciences, [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] * Department of Forestry and Natural Resources, [[Purdue University]] * Department of Natural Resource Ecology and Management, [[Iowa State University]] * School of Natural Resources & Environment, [[University of Michigan]] * [[University of Minnesota College of Food, Agricultural and Natural Resource Sciences|College of Food, Agricultural and Natural Resource Sciences]], [[University of Minnesota]] * [[University of Missouri College of Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources|College of Agriculture, Food and Natural Resources]], [[University of Missouri]] * School of Natural Resources, [[Ohio State University]] * College of Natural Resources, [[University of Wisconsin–Stevens Point]]
===South=== * School of Renewable Natural Resources, [[Louisiana State University]] * College of Natural Resources, [[North Carolina State University]] * Department of Natural Resource Ecology and Management, [[Oklahoma State University]] * [[Daniel B. Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources]], [[University of Georgia]] * [[Virginia Tech College of Natural Resources and Environment|College of Natural Resources and Environment]], [[Virginia Tech]]
===West=== * Department of Natural Resources Management, [[California Polytechnic State University]] * [[Oklahoma State University College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources|College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources]], [[Oklahoma State University]] * [[Texas Tech University College of Agricultural Sciences & Natural Resources|College of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources]], [[Texas Tech University]] * [[University of California, Berkeley College of Natural Resources|College of Natural Resources]], [[University of California, Berkeley]] * College of Natural Resources, Department of Forest Ecology and Biogeosciences, [[University of Idaho]] * [[University of Wyoming#The Helga Otto Haub School of Environment and Natural Resources|The Helga Otto Haub School of Environment and Natural Resources]], [[University of Wyoming]] * [[Washington State University College of Agricultural, Human, and Natural Resource Sciences|College of Agricultural, Human, and Natural Resource Sciences]], [[Washington State University]] * Quinney College of Natural Resources, [[Utah State University]]

This is an incomplete list of [[plants]] with trifoliate leaves. '''Trifoliate''' leaves (also known as '''trifoliolate''' or '''ternate''' leaves) are a [[leaf shape]] characterized by a leaf divided into three leaflets. Species which are known to be trifoliate are listed here. Genera which are characteristically trifoliate are also listed, with species underneath. Genera which are generally ''not'' trifoliate are not listed; only the trifoliate species are. Entries are currently listed in alphabetical order, but in the future it may be desirable to list them by families. It may also be desirable to include common names and references.

revision.text:
In [[ancient Greek religion]] and [[Greek mythology|mythology]], '''Melia''' ([[Ancient Greek]]: Μελία), a daughter of the [[Titan (mythology)|Titan]] [[Oceanus]], was the consort of [[Apollo]], and the mother, by Apollo, of the [[Thebes, Greece|Theban]] hero and prophet [[Tenerus (son of Apollo)|Tenerus]]. She was also the mother (or sister) of [[Ismenus]], god of the Theban river of the same name. Melia was an important cult figure at [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]]. She was worshipped at the Ismenion, the Temple of Apollo at Thebes, and was associated with a nearby spring.
==Mythology== The late 6th–early 5th century BC [[Thebes, Greece|Theban]] poet [[Pindar]] tells us that Melia, a daughter of Oceanus, was, by [[Apollo]], the mother of the Theban hero and prophet '''Tenerus'''.<ref>Larson, pp. 40–41, 142; [[Pindar]], ''Paean 9'' fr. 52k 34–46 (Race 1997b, [https://www.loebclassics.com/view/pindar-fragments/1997/pb_LCL485.293.xml?rskey=uUnpv2&result=1&mainRsKey=al0jlH pp. 292–295]; Rutherford, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gPjZOB1YNqAC&pg=PA191 pp. 191–192]); also [[Strabo]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0099.tlg001.perseus-eng1:9.2.34 9.2.34], which says that the "Teneric Plain" was named after Tenerus the son of Melia and Apollo.</ref> Elsewhere he refers to her as "Melia of the golden spindle".<ref>[[Pindar]], fr. 29 1 (Race 1997b, [https://www.loebclassics.com/view/pindar-fragments/1997/pb_LCL485.233.xml?mainRsKey=KX3fcB&result=2&rskey=U8dE7v pp. 232, 233]).</ref> The 2nd century AD Greek geographer [[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] provides a more complete account.<ref> Larson, p. 142; Schachter 1967, p. 4; Fontenrose [https://books.google.com/books?id=wqeVv09Y6hIC&pg=PA317, pp. 317–318]; [[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.+9.10.5 9.10.5], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.+9.10.6 6], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.+9.26.1 9.26.1].</ref> According to Pausanias, Melia was abducted, and Melia's father Oceanus ordered his son [[Caanthus]] to find her. Caanthus found Melia at [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]] being held by Apollo, but unable to get Melia away from Apollo, Caanthus set fire to Apollo's sanctuary, and Apollo shot and killed him. Pausanius says that, in addition to Tenerus, to whom Apollo gave the "art of divination", Melia had another son by Apollo, [[Ismenus]], after whom the Theban river Ismenus was named.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.+9.10.6 9.10.6]; c.f. [[Pindar]], fr. 29 1 (Race 1997b, [https://www.loebclassics.com/view/pindar-fragments/1997/pb_LCL485.233.xml?mainRsKey=KX3fcB&result=2&rskey=U8dE7v pp. 232, 233]). For the Theban Ismenus river, see Berman, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zoeSBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA18 p. 18].</ref>
The story of Melia and Caanthus, as recorded by Pausainus, is a close parallel to the more famous story of [[Europa (consort of Zeus)|Europa]] and [[Cadmus]], the founder and first king of Thebes. Like Melia, Europa is abducted by an Olympian god (in this case [[Zeus]]), and her brother Cadmus is sent by their father to bring Europa back home, but like Caanthus, Cadmus is unsuccessful.<ref>Larson, p. 142, describes the story as "clearly a doublet of the better-known myth" of Cadmus and Europa"; Schachter 1967, p. 4, calls Melia's story an "imitation" of the story of Cadmus and Europa; see also Schachter 1981, p. 79; Fontenrose, p. 318. Compare with the story of the Theban [[Amphion]] (see below).</ref> As noted by [[Joseph Fontenrose|Fontenrose]], there are other apparent congruences between the Theban Melia and Europa.<ref>Fontenrose, p. 318.</ref> Like Melia, Europa was also the name of an Oceanid,<ref>[[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+349 357]; [[Andron|Andron of Halicarnassus]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=j0nRE4C2WBgC&pg=PA42 fr. 7 Fowler] = ''[[FGrHist]]'' 10 F 7 (Fowler 2013, [https://books.google.com/books?id=scd8AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA13 p. 13]).</ref> and [[Agenor]], the usual father of Europa, had, according to the fifth-century BC mythographer [[Pherecydes of Athens|Pherecydes]], a daughter named Melia who was a wife of [[Danaus]],<ref>Gantz, p. 208; [[Pherecydes of Athens|Pherecydes]] fr. 21 Fowler 2001, p. 289 = ''[[FGrHist]]'' 3 F 21 = Scholia on [[Apollonius of Rhodes|Apollonius Rhodius]], ''[[Argonautica]]'' 3.1177-87f.</ref> while, according to the mythographer Apollodrus, one of Danaos' wife's was also named Europa.<ref>[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:2.1.5 2.1.5].</ref>
There were apparently other versions of this Theban Melia's story.<ref>Schachter 1967, p. 4.</ref> In some traditions perhaps, the Thebans Melia and Ismenus were siblings, rather than mother and son. A scholiast on Pindar says that Ismenus was Melia's brother.<ref>Larson, p. 304 n. 57; Fontenrose, p. 319; Scholia on [[Pindar]], ''Pythian'' 11.5–6 (Drachmann, [https://archive.org/details/scholiaveterainp02drac/page/254 pp. 254–255]).</ref> According to the [[Oxyrhynchus Papyri]], the first fratricide occurred at Thebes when Melia's brothers, Ismenus and Claaitus (a corruption or variant of Caanthus?) fought over her.<ref>Schachter 1967, p. 4; Fontenrose, p. 319; ''[[Oxyrhynchus Papyri]]'' X 1241.4.5–10 (Grenfell and Hunt, pp. [https://archive.org/details/oxyrhynchusppt1000grenuoft/page/104/mode/1up 104: Greek text], [https://archive.org/details/oxyrhynchusppt1000grenuoft/page/109/mode/1up 109: translation], [https://archive.org/details/oxyrhynchusppt1000grenuoft/page/110/mode/1up 110: commentary]).</ref>
A version of Melia's story perhaps also involved the Theban [[Amphion]].<ref>Schachter 1967, p. 4.</ref> Pherecydes says that Melia was the name of one of the daughters of [[Amphion]] and his wife [[Niobe]],<ref>Fowler 2013, [https://books.google.com/books?id=scd8AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA367 p. 367]; Schachter 1967, p. 4; [[Pherecydes of Athens|Pherecydes]] fr. 126 Fowler 2001, p. 342 = ''[[FGrHist]]'' 3 F 126 = Scholia on [[Euripides]], ''[[Phoenician Women]]'' 159.</ref> while later sources tell us that Ismenus was the name of one of their sons.<ref>Schechter 1967, p. 4; [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:3.5.6 3.5.6]; [[Ovid]], ''[[Metamorphoses]]'' [https://www.loebclassics.com/view/ovid-metamorphoses/1916/pb_LCL042.303.xml 6.221–224]; [[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' 11 (Smith and Trzaskoma, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA100 p. 100]). </ref> Like Caanthus, Amphion was shot and killed by Apollo because of an attack on his temple.<ref>[[Hyginus]], ''[[Fabulae]]'' 9 (Smith and Trzaskoma, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vczTNMWLGdoC&pg=PA99 p. 99]).</ref>
The 3rd century BC poet [[Callimachus]] appears to make this Theban Melia, rather than a daughter of Oceanus, one of the "earth-born" [[Meliae]], the ash tree nymphs, who, according to [[Hesiod]], were born, along with the [[Erinyes]] and the [[Giants (Greek mythology)|Giants]], from Gaia (Earth) and the blood of [[Uranus (mythology)|Uranus]] (Sky), which dripped on Gaia when Uranus was castrated by his son [[Cronus]].<ref> Larson, p. 142; [[Callimachus]], ''Hymn 4—To Delos'' [https://archive.org/stream/callimachuslycop00calluoft#page/90/mode/2up 79–85 with note i]; [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+187 187].</ref>
According to the mythographer [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], the mother of [[Phoroneus]], and [[Aegialeus (King of Sicyon)|Aegialeus]], by her brother, the river god [[Inachus]], was also a daughter of [[Oceanus]] named [[Melia (consort of Inachus)|Melia]].<ref>Grimal, s.v. Melia 2, p. 281; [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Apollodorus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0548.tlg001.perseus-eng1:2.1.1 2.1.1].</ref>
===Cult=== Melia was an important object of cult worship at the Ismenion, the major sanctuary of Apollo Ismenios at Thebes.<ref>Larson, p. 142; Berman, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=zoeSBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA64 64], [https://books.google.com/books?id=zoeSBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA124 124]; Schachter 1967, p. 5, which calls her an "important component of the cult complex" at the Ismenion; for the Ismenion, and the cult of Melia, see Schachter 1981, pp. 77–88 (Melia: p. 78); Schachter 1967, pp. 3–5.</ref> In at least three separate poems, Pindar mentions Melia in connection with the Theban sanctuary. In one he refers to the Ismenion and "the splendid hall of Oceanus’ daughter . . . Melia".<ref>[[Pindar]], ''Paean 7'' fr. 52g (Race 1997b, [https://www.loebclassics.com/view/pindar-fragments/1997/pb_LCL485.279.xml?mainRsKey=KX3fcB&result=3&rskey=U8dE7v pp. 278, 279] ; Rutherford, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gPjZOB1YNqAC&pg=PA339 p. 339]).</ref> In another, Pindar summons the local heroines, the daughters of Cadmus, [[Semele]] and [[Ino (Greek mythology)|Ino Leucothea]], along with the mother of [[Heracles]], to "join Melia at the treasury of the golden tripods,"<ref>Larson, p. 142; Rutherford, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gPjZOB1YNqAC&pg=PA341 p. 341]; [[Pindar]], ''Pythian'' 11.4–6 (Race 1997a, [https://www.loebclassics.com/view/pindar-pythian_odes/1997/pb_LCL056.381.xml?result=5&rskey=HX9pmG pp. 380, 381]); c.f. [[Herodotus]], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0016.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.52 1.52].</ref> that is in the ''[[adyton]]'', the inner inviolate sanctuary of the Ismenion where the votive tripods were dedicated.<ref>Schachter 2016, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YfA4DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA267 p. 267], which further supposes that Melia would have had a cult image, perhaps made of ash wood; see also Schachter 1981, pp. 82–83; Schachter 1967, p. 5.</ref> Also at the Ismenion, Pindar locates the "immortal couch [''λέχει''] of Melia",<ref>[[Pindar]], ''Paean 9'' fr. 52k 35 (Race 1997b, [https://www.loebclassics.com/view/pindar-fragments/1997/pb_LCL485.293.xml?rskey=uUnpv2&result=1&mainRsKey=al0jlH pp. 292–293]; Rutherford, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gPjZOB1YNqAC&pg=PA191 p. 191]).</ref> the child-bed, where Melia gave birth.<ref>Berman, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=zoeSBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA64 64]; Rutherford, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gPjZOB1YNqAC&pg=PA196 196], [https://books.google.com/books?id=gPjZOB1YNqAC&pg=PA341 341].</ref> A spring near the Ismenion was identified with Melia, perhaps the source of the Ismenus river, and perhaps the same spring as the one mentioned by Pausanias as the spring, above the Ismenion, by which her brother Caanthus was buried.<ref>Larson, p. 142; Schachter 1967, p. 5 with note 30; Fontenrose, p. 318; Scholia on [[Pindar]] ''Pythian'' 11.6 (Drachmann, [https://archive.org/details/scholiaveterainp02drac/page/255 p. 255]), which says the spring had the same name as the "heroine" Melia, daughter of Oceanus; [[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.+9.10.5 9.10.5].</ref>
The Thebans traced their descent from the union of Apollo and Melia, through the heroes Tenerus and Ismenus. According to Larson, while their descent from Apollo—a panhellenic Olympian god—increased their prestige, and connected them to other Greeks, their descent from Melia—a nymph associated with the local landscape—helped to establish their connection with the land that they inhabited.<ref>Larson, pp. 40–41.</ref>

{{Other uses|Melite (mythology)}}
In [[Greek mythology]], '''Melite''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ɛ|l|ᵻ|t|iː}}; [[Ancient Greek]]: Μελίτη) was one of the [[Naiads]], daughter of the river god [[Aegaeus]], and one of the many loves of [[Zeus]] and his son [[Heracles]]. Given the choice, she chose Heracles over Zeus who went off in search of other pursuits. She gave birth to Hercules's son [[Hyllus]]; some suggest that he was a figure distinct from Hyllus, the son of Heracles by [[Deianeira]].<ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 4. 1149</ref>
== Mythology == Heracles tried to find refuge on the mythical island of [[Scheria]], widely considered to be the island of [[Corfu]] in modern Greece, after the murder of his children. He decided to rest near a lake. This lake happened to be the place in which Melite and her sisters were currently residing. When Melite saw Hercules she hid him away from her siblings in a deeper and darker part of the lake where she had sex with him. The two then traveled to another part of the island and stayed there until Melite gave birth to Hyllus.<ref>[[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 4. 538 ff</ref>
Zeus was in a rage over her choice of a mortal over him, and so he appealed to her father who would not let her have anymore children with Hercules or any sexual contact whatsoever. Hercules promptly left Melite for other mortals. She was one of the women who were there mourning the death of Hercules.
Hyllus did not want to be a mere subject to King [[Nausithous]], so he traveled to the far north of Greece, where he became king and [[eponym]] of a non-Greek tribe, the Hylleis.<ref>[[Scholia]] on [[Apollonius Rhodius]], ''Argonautica'', 4. 524, 540, 1125, 1149; [[Stephanus of Byzantium]], s. v. ''Hylleis''; ''[[Etymologicum Magnum]]'' 776. 40 under ''Hylēōn''</ref>

{{Taxobox | image = Mesobuthus eupeus in human hand.jpg | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Arthropod]]a | classis = [[Arachnid]]a | ordo = [[Scorpion]]es | familia = [[Buthidae]] | genus = ''[[Mesobuthus]]'' | species = '''''M. eupeus''''' | binomial = ''Mesobuthus eupeus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Carl Ludwig Koch|Koch]], 1839) | synonyms = *''Buthus eupeus'' <small>Koch, 1839</small> | synonyms_ref =  <ref name=NCBI-Tax34648>{{NCBI|34648|''Mesobuthus eupeus''}}</ref><ref name=UniProt-Tax34648>[https://www.uniprot.org/taxonomy/34648 ''Mesobuthus eupeus'' (Lesser Asian scorpion) ''(Buthus eupeus)''], [[UniProt]] Taxonomy database</ref> }}
'''''Mesobuthus eupeus''''' is a [[Polymorphism (biology)|polymorphic]] [[scorpion]] [[species]] belonging to the well-known [[family (biology)|family]] [[Buthidae]]. Commonly known as the '''lesser Asian scorpion''' or the '''mottled scorpion'''. It is thought to be the most widely dispersed species of the ''[[Mesobuthus]]'' [[genus]], perhaps even of the family Buthidae.<ref name=NCBI-Tax34648/><ref name=UniProt-Tax34648/><ref name="shi">{{cite journal |author1=Cheng-Min Shi |author2=Zu-Shi Huang |author3=Lei Wang |author4=Li-Jun He |author5=Yue-Ping Hua |author6=Liang Leng |author7=De-Xing Zhang |year=2007 |title=Geographical distribution of two species of ''Mesobuthus'' (Scorpiones, Buthidae) in China: insights from systematic field surveys and predictive models |journal=[[Journal of Arachnology]] |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=215–226 |jstor=25067833 |doi=10.1636/T06-20.1 |url=http://www.americanarachnology.org/JoA_free/JoA_v35_n2/arac-35-2-215.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}</ref>
==Description== ''M. eupeus'' can reach a size of {{convert|4|to|5|cm}} in length. The entire body is yellow to yellowish brown. The dorsal segments ([[tergite]]s) of the [[mesosoma]] often have longitudinal irregular stripes that are black to dark brown.<ref name="shi"/> They exhibit [[sexual dimorphism]], the adult females being generally larger than males but have a lower number of [[Pecten (Arachnid)|pectinal teeth]] (16 to 23, as opposed to 22 to 28 in males).<ref name="turkey"/>
The [[pedipalp]]s of ''M. eupeus'' have a maximum of ten diagonal rows of granules on the fixed finger and eleven on the movable finger. The pedipalp [[Pincer (biology)|chela]]e (pincers) are wider than the patella (segment IV). The segments of the [[metasoma]] are thick and have eight keels (octocarinate). The [[telson]] is subglobose with a flat dorsal surface.<ref name="turkey"/>
==Taxonomy== ''M. eupeus'' were first described by the [[German people|German]] [[arachnologist]] [[Carl Ludwig Koch]] in 1839. It is classified under the genus ''Mesobuthus'' and belongs to the largest [[family (biology)|family]] of scorpions, the thick-tailed scorpion family [[Buthidae]].<ref name="shi"/> Currently, more than 23 [[subspecies]] of ''M. eupeus'' are recognized.<ref name="teruel">{{cite journal|author=Teruel, Rolando|year=2002|title=First Record of ''Mesobuthus eupeus'' (Kock, 1939) from Western Turkey (Scorpiones: Buthidae)|journal=Revista Ibérica de Aracnología|volume=5|issue=31–VII|pages=75–76|issn=1576-9518|url=http://www.sea-entomologia.org/PDF/RIA_5/R05-013-075.pdf }}</ref>
==Ecology== ''M. eupeus'' feed on small insects such as [[cricket (insect)|crickets]] or small [[cockroach]]es.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f23mioGRlR0 |title=''Mesobuthus eupeus'' feeding |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=28 June 2006}}</ref> [[Cannibalism]] is very rare in this species. They do not dig burrows and prefer using natural spaces and burrows under stones and other objects. They have slender [[pedipalps]] so they usually rely on their stings for killing their prey.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Dong Sun |author2=Zhen-Ning Sun |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2011 |title=Notes on the genus ''Mesobuthus'' (Scorpiones: Buthidae) in China, with description of a new species |journal=[[Journal of Arachnology]] |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=59–75 |doi=10.1636/Ha10-36.1}}</ref>
==Venom== The venom of ''M. eupeus'' is not as potent as that of other dangerous buthid species.<ref name="Ahmadi2009">{{cite journal |author1=M. Ahmadi |author2=A. Zare Mirakabadi |author3=M. Hashemlou |author4=M. Hejazi |year=2009 |title=Study on anti inflammatory effect of scorpion ''(Mesobuthus eupeus)'' venom in adjuvant-induced arthritis in rats |journal=Archives of Razi Institute |volume=64 |issue=1 |pages=51–56 |url=http://sid.ir/en/VEWSSID/J_pdf/83520090107.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}</ref> Victims of stings feel intense pain, hyperemia, swelling and a burning sensation in the affected area, while numbness and itching were also reported in some cases.<ref name="Ozkan&Kat, 2005">{{cite journal|last=Ozkan|first=O.|author2=Kat, I.|date=Oct 30, 2005|title=''Mesobuthus eupeus'' scorpionism in Sanliurfa region of Turkey|journal=J. Venom. Anim. Toxins Incl. Trop. Dis|volume=11|issue=4|pages=479–491|issn=1678-9199|url=http://www.scielo.br/pdf/jvatitd/v11n4/v11n4a08.pdf|accessdate=Sep 20, 2011 | doi = 10.1590/S1678-91992005000400008 }}</ref>
As in other scorpions, the venom of ''M. eupeus'' contains various neurotoxic proteins that interact specifically with ion channels. A number of unique proteins in this scorpion's venom have been identified,<ref name="UniProtKB">{{cite web|url=https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/?query=organism%3a34648&offset=0|title=Results for organism:"''Buthus eupeus'' (Lesser Asian scorpion) (''Mesobuthus eupeus'') <nowiki>[34648]</nowiki>" in UniProtKB|work=[[UniProtKB]]|publisher=[[UniProt|UniProt Consortium]]|accessdate=Sep 18, 2011}}</ref> cloned and investigated for clinical applications. For instance, MeuKTX, structurally related to BmKTX (α-KTx3.6) from ''[[Mesobuthus martensii|M. martensii]]'', potently inhibits rKv1.1, rKv1.2 and hKv1.3 channels but does not affect rKv1.4, rKv1.5, hKv3.1, rKv4.3, and hERG channels even at high concentrations.<ref name=pmid20713119>{{Cite journal | pmid = 20713119 | year = 2010 | last1 = Gao | first1 = B | last2 = Peigneur | first2 = S | last3 = Tytgat | first3 = J | last4 = Zhu | first4 = S | title = A potent potassium channel blocker from Mesobuthus eupeus scorpion venom | volume = 92 | issue = 12 | pages = 1847–53 | doi = 10.1016/j.biochi.2010.08.003 | journal = Biochimie | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref> In contrast, BeKm-1 specifically inhibits [[hERG]] channels,<ref name=pmid11136720>{{Cite journal | pmid = 11136720 | year = 2001 | last1 = Korolkova | first1 = YV | last2 = Kozlov | first2 = SA | last3 = Lipkin | first3 = AV | last4 = Pluzhnikov | first4 = KA | last5 = Hadley | first5 = JK | last6 = Filippov | first6 = AK | last7 = Brown | first7 = DA | last8 = Angelo | first8 = K | last9 = Strøbaek | first9 = D | last10 = Jespersen | first10 = T | last11 = Olesen | first11 = S. P. | last12 = Jensen | first12 = B. S. | last13 = Grishin | first13 = E. V. | title = An ERG channel inhibitor from the scorpion Buthus eupeus | volume = 276 | issue = 13 | pages = 9868–76 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M005973200 | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | display-authors = 8 }}</ref> which are potassium channels critical to maintaining normal electrical activities in the heart,<ref name="pmid16554806">{{cite journal |vauthors=Sanguinetti MC, Tristani-Firouzi M |title=hERG potassium channels and cardiac arrhythmia |journal=Nature |volume=440 |issue=7083 |pages=463–9 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16554806 |doi=10.1038/nature04710 |url=}}</ref> but showed no effects on various other potassium channels tested.<ref name="pmid11136720" /> Inhibitors of sodium channels have also been found in this venom.<ref name=pmid10491073>{{Cite journal | pmid = 21763288 | year = 2011 | last1 = Gao | first1 = B | last2 = Zhu | first2 = L | last3 = Zhu | first3 = S | title = A naturally-occurring carboxyl-terminally truncated α-scorpion toxin is a blocker of sodium channels | volume = 411 | issue = 4 | pages = 673–8 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbrc.2011.06.178 | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications }}</ref><ref name=pmid21763288>{{Cite journal | pmid = 10491073 | year = 1999 | last1 = Possani | first1 = LD | last2 = Becerril | first2 = B | last3 = Delepierre | first3 = M | last4 = Tytgat | first4 = J | title = Scorpion toxins specific for Na+-channels | volume = 264 | issue = 2 | pages = 287–300 | journal = European Journal of Biochemistry / FEBS | doi=10.1046/j.1432-1327.1999.00625.x}}</ref>
A number of [[antimicrobial peptide]]s have also been found in the venom of ''M. eupeus''. Meucin-13 and Meucin-18 exhibited extensive [[cytolytic]] effects on bacteria, fungi and yeasts.<ref name=pmid19088182>{{Cite journal| pmid = 19088182 | doi=10.1096/fj.08-122317| title=Structural and functional characterization of two genetically related meucin peptides highlights evolutionary divergence and convergence in antimicrobial peptides| journal=The FASEB Journal| volume=23| issue=4| pages=1230–45| year=2008| last1=Gao| first1=B.| last2=Sherman| first2=P.| last3=Luo| first3=L.| last4=Bowie| first4=J.| last5=Zhu| first5=S.| postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> Furthermore, Meucin-24 and Meucin-25, first identified from genetic sequences expressed in their venom gland, were shown to selectively kill ''[[Plasmodium falciparum]]'' and inhibit the development of ''[[Plasmodium berghei]]'', both [[malaria]] parasites, but do not harm mammalian cells. These two venom-derived proteins are therefore attractive candidates for the development of [[Antimalarial medication|anti-malarial drugs]].<ref name=pmid20097251>{{Cite journal | pmid = 20097251 | year = 2010 | last1 = Gao | first1 = B | last2 = Xu | first2 = J | last3 = Rodriguez Mdel | first3 = C | last4 = Lanz-Mendoza | first4 = H | last5 = Hernández-Rivas | first5 = R | last6 = Du | first6 = W | last7 = Zhu | first7 = S | title = Characterization of two linear cationic antimalarial peptides in the scorpion Mesobuthus eupeus | volume = 92 | issue = 4 | pages = 350–9 | doi = 10.1016/j.biochi.2010.01.011 | journal = Biochimie }}</ref>
Iranian researchers have also reported that the venom of ''M. eupeus'' has [[anti-inflammatory]] properties and is effective as an anti-[[arthritis]] treatment in an experimental rat model, but the mechanism of action is unknown.<ref name="Ahmadi2009"/>
==Habitat and distribution== ''Mesobuthus eupeus'' mostly lives in [[arid]] or semi-arid habitats with little or no [[vegetation]]. Its geographical distributions consists of eastern [[Turkey]],<ref name="turkey">{{cite journal |author1=Ayşegül Karataş |author2=Ahmet Karataş |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2003 |title=''Mesobuthus eupeus'' (C.L. Koch, 1839) (Scorpiones: Buthidae) in Turkey |journal=Euscorpius — Occasional Publications in Scorpiology |volume=7 |pages=1–6 |url=http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2003_07.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}</ref> [[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], southern [[Russia]], northern [[Syria]], eastern [[Iraq]], [[Iran]],<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Omid Mirshamsi |author2=Alireza Sari |author3=Elahe Elahi |author4=Shidokht Hosseinie |year=2011 |title=''Mesobuthus eupeus'' (Scorpiones: Buthidae) from Iran: a polytypic species complex |journal=[[Zootaxa]] |volume=2929 |pages=1–21 |url=http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/z02929p021f.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}</ref> [[Afghanistan]], [[Pakistan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Uzbekistan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Tajikistan]], [[Kazakhstan]], Australia, southern [[Mongolia]] and northern [[China]].{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
== List of subspecies == {{Unreferenced|date=March 2018}} * ''Mesobuthus eupeus eupeus'' (C. L. Koch, 1839) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus afghanus'' (Pocock, 1889) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus barszczewskii'' (Birula, 1904) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus bogdoensis'' (Birula, 1896) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus haarlovi'' Vachon, 1958 * ''Mesobuthus eupeus iranus'' (Birula, 1917) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus kirmanensis'' (Birula, 1900) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus mesopotamicus'' ([[Arnold Penther|Penther]], 1912) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus mongolicus'' (Birula, 1911) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus pachysoma'' (Birula, 1900) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus persicus'' (Pocock, 1899) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus philippovitschi'' (Birula, 1905) * ''Mesobuthus eupeus thersites'' (C. L. Koch, 1839)

'''<nowiki/>[[National park|National nature park]]s of [[Ukraine]]''' are preservation territories that are part of the Nature-Preservation Fund of Ukraine. The total area protected by national parks is approximately {{convert|1111600|ha|km2}}, for an average of {{convert|22685|ha|km2}} but a [[median]] of only {{convert|14836|ha|km2}} at [[National Nature Park Zalissya|Zalissya]]. The largest national park is [[Upper Pobozhia National Nature Park|Upper Pobozhia]] in [[Khmelnytskyi Oblast]]: at over {{convert|100000|ha|km2}}. The smallest park is [[Derman-Ostroh National Nature Park]], at less than {{convert|5500|ha|km2}}.
This category of the Nature-Preservation Fund was mainly established after the fall of the [[Soviet Union]]. There were very few parks in Ukraine and most of them were in the [[West Ukraine|West]].
